name: TheAtlantic
text: “You about to lose yo job,” a months-old warning from a Black woman to the officer detaining her, has become the protest song of the moment. @skornhaber on how demonstrators are creating new political anthems: https://t.co/5iroPDODmy

name: TheAtlantic
text: A new poem by @officialdonika: "I think of you, in the spring soon come. / Friend, should you give a holler from your porch," https://t.co/0kyisSYWWU

name: TheAtlantic
text:
Hundreds of centuries-old European shipwrecks seem to have vanished without a trace. The suspected culprit? Worms, writes @MatthewHalliday. 
https://t.co/O1PNQK9O6p

name: TheAtlantic
text: A press conference so bizarre, it demanded poetry. James Parker's ode to Philadelphia's other Four Seasons: https://t.co/g640gmfiCK

name: TheAtlantic
text: “FDT,” this era’s signature protest song, attracted attention for its outrage against Donald Trump, @skornhaber writes. But the track’s co-writer, the late Nipsey Hussle, knew that through carefully crafted verses, the song's message could create unity. https://t.co/lXBcPKb44x

name: TheAtlantic
text: From Buffalo, through the Finger Lakes, to the Hudson Valley, Manhattan, and more, here are a few glimpses of the landscape of New York, and some of the wildlife and people calling it home—via @TheAtlPhoto: https://t.co/7kl9Wq4nue

name: TheAtlantic
text: "You can’t understand the present without seeing the connections between this history and the socioeconomic and racial imbalances it created." Chuck Yarborough talked to @KristinaRizga about resetting students' understanding of the Civil War: https://t.co/SjeoMojbz9
